During one of the first performances on the 2016 GRAMMY Awards, country artists Sam Hunt and Carrie Underwood sang Huntâ€™s hit, â€œTake Your Time.â€ As I was passively listening, I started to think to myself, â€˜Wait a minute, why do I know these lyrics?â€™ Then it hit me, â€˜Thatâ€™s Adrian Marcelâ€™s song!â€™ I thought Hunt was covering Marcelâ€™s original song and I started to get upset; but after a quick google search, I found out that the song indeed belonged to Sam Hunt. I calmed down then LOL but I had been totally oblivious to the fact that Marcelâ€™s cover was even a cover because I donâ€™t follow country music like I used to. Realizing that this country song was covered by an R&B artist made me wonder how often thatâ€™s done today.

Rhapsody.com touched on this very topic when explaining their playlist, â€œR&B Covers Country.â€ The website called the practice of R&B acts covering country songs â€œa phenomenon that used to happen all the time through the mid-â€™70s or so, but for some reason has grown rarer and rarer ever sinceâ€¦Where singers like Al Green, Solomon Burke, Bobby Womack and Millie Jackson once upon a time regularly included country standards in their repertoires (sometimes recording entire albums of them, such as Womackâ€™s 1976 BW Does C&W), it might be impossible to find even isolated equivalents in catalogs of, say, R. Kelly or Brian McKnight or Jill Scott.â€

Thatâ€™s an interesting point. The majority of the time, we hear R&B artists cover classic R&B which is great i.e., R. Kelly has covered Sam Cookeâ€™s catalog during some of his live shows and does justice to the legendâ€™s music. Now could the â€œPied-Piper of R&Bâ€ sound just as good covering some country music? Absolutely! True, none of todayâ€™s R&B artists need to cover a country song with some soul flavor for higher career achievement or just for the heck of it, but we know they could definitely be successful if they chose to go that route. Rhapsody.com added, â€œWhitney Houstonâ€™s take on Dolly Partonâ€™s â€œI Will Always Love Youâ€ obviously went stratospheric in 1992, and two years later All-4-One had almost as much luck with John Michael Montgomeryâ€™s â€œI Swear.â€

Initially, it might sound a little weird to hear an R&B artist do a cover (or an â€œinterpretationâ€, as Will Downing would say) of a country song, but country songs are known for telling great stories and R&B vocalists have a special way of expressing their pleasure and pain that tug at the heartstrings. That link makes the genres more like brother and sister as opposed to distant cousins. As a matter of fact, during the recording of the 1994 album, â€œRhythm, Country and Bluesâ€ â€“ which featured duets with R&B and country artists â€“ country legend Reba McEntire made this comment :â€œIâ€™ve always said that if you can get the emotion, the deep-down gutsy feeling of R&B, and the very relatable lyrics from country, youâ€™ve got a monster song.â€ I couldnâ€™t agree more! There was a time in my childhood when I primarily listened to country music and thus gained an affinity for artists such as Trisha Yearwood, Shania Twain, The Rascal Flatts, and Blake Shelton. I still have several favorites from that period and a few from nowadays, and it would be awesome to hear some of those great stories covered in an R&B style by the likes of Mary J. Blige, Monica, Mint Condition and Anthony Hamilton, just to name a few.

â€œIâ€™ve always said that if you can get the emotion, the deep-down gutsy feeling of R&B, and the very relatable lyrics from country, youâ€™ve got a monster song.â€ â€“ Reba McEntire

In my tiny estimation, doing an â€œinterpretationâ€ of a song in another genre is equivalent to singing a song in a personâ€™s mother tongue, in a style that will touch the heart of the listener. So the average R&B fan who may have never listened to Dolly Parton is guaranteed to love at least one of her songs â€“ â€œI Will Always Love Youâ€ â€“ because of how Whitney Houston interpreted it. And the average R&B fan who may have never listened to John Michael Montgomery probably likes at least two of his songs â€“ â€œI Swearâ€ and â€œI Can Love You Like Thatâ€ â€“ because of how All-4-One interpreted them. Though the lyrics of the aforementioned songs didnâ€™t change when interpreted in the R&B â€œlanguageâ€, the production and style of singing underwent a â€œsoul treatmentâ€, thus resonating more with an urban audience.

While obviously still a rarity, hereâ€™s a list of a few examples within recent years of R&B acts covering country songs, which predate Adrian Marcelâ€™s take on Sam Huntâ€™s â€œTake Your Time.â€ See how many youâ€™ve heard of â€“>

On her 2004 debut album, â€œFree Yourself,â€ Fantasia interprets â€œYou Were Always On My Mindâ€, a song that was originally recorded by Gwen McCrae and Brenda Lee but popularized by Willie Nelson in 1982.

Joe interprets â€œBefore He Cheatsâ€ by Carrie Underwood, singing it from the male perspective and calling it â€œBefore I Cheat.â€ Rather than for an album, Joe covers this song for Yahoo! Musicâ€™s series, â€œCover Artâ€, circa 2006.

Gladys Knight did her own rendition of Lee Ann Womackâ€™s â€œI Hope You Danceâ€ for the 2008 Tyler Perry movie, â€œThe Family That Preys.â€

Boyz II Men interpret â€œAmazedâ€ by Lonestar for their 2009 cover album, â€œLove.â€ According to one report, Shawn Stockman said that B2M was offered the song first but turned it down.

Tamia interprets â€œIs It Over Yetâ€ by Wynonna Judd on her 2012 album, â€œBeautiful Surprise.â€ (Interestingly, Tamia loves country music and she covered her own song, â€œStillâ€, in a country style for the same album. Itâ€™s a really neat track!)

2016 Honorable Mention: Rapper Nelly â€“ who has collaborated with country artists Tim McGraw and Florida Georgia Line during his career â€“ released a cover of Thomas Rhettâ€™s â€œDie a Happy Manâ€ in February 2016.

2017 addition: KeKe Wyatt, a powerhouse vocalist and die-hard lover of country music, puts her smooth spin on Chris Stapletonâ€™s cover of â€œTennessee Whiskeyâ€ for her 2017 album, â€œKeke Covers.â€ This is on constant rotation in my house. ğŸ™‚

So, what do you think of those â€œinterpretationsâ€? Clearly, R&B vocalists today have no problem making a country song their own and sounding good while doing it, just as their musical predecessors did back in the day. It may not be done as often now as it was then, but Iâ€™m all for hearing more of it. What say you?

Thereâ€™s nothing as classy and cool as a group of soul men who can dance as well as they can sing; no Iâ€™m not talking about displaying the acrobatic talent of a Chris Brown or the MJ-esque moves of Ne-Yo, but the choreography presented by a vocal group thatâ€™s marked by precision and poise. Choreography that corresponds to the narratorâ€™s lyrics brings the story to life, adding splashes of color to the canvas that is the stage. (You can sense that I love dancing, right?)

That said, itâ€™s not that entertaining or show-stopping when a group of singing men blend their voices without any accompanying steps, unless, of course, the song can stand alone with a dramatic/reflective plot or melody i.e. Four Topsâ€™ â€œI Believe in You and Meâ€, The Temptationsâ€™ â€œJust My Imaginationâ€ and Boyz II Menâ€™s â€œMama.â€ In my opinion, just enough appropriate, well-chosen moves and grooves can make a performance more interesting and keep the audienceâ€™s attention throughout the showcase. (Long gone are the days when black artists who formed doo-wop groups didnâ€™t put much emphasis on moving their feet, but focused more on harmonizing their vocal â€œoohsâ€ and â€œahhs.â€)

Now, when it comes to fine-tuned choreography amongst soul groups, The Temptations are viewed as the cream of the crop; I have no desire to dispute this assertion because, in their heyday (especially with the â€œclassic fiveâ€ lineup), Motownâ€™s quintessential male vocal group were bad to the bone. No matter who was leading a particular song, it was guaranteed that the other four members would not only harmonize but slide, step, spin and snap in unison, making for one dynamite showcase of entertainment.

I mean, they had their own â€œTemptations Walkâ€ that they sprinkled in every so often during a set and, whenever they concluded a performance, they didnâ€™t simply bow to salute the crowd. Instead, each gentleman clutched his fist in a downward motion, stepped his right foot out then slid it back to meet the left and bowed with and open hand as their right foot crossed their left which remained stationary. You canâ€™t beat that!

While The â€œClassic Fiveâ€ Temptations are regarded as the best of the best because of their popularity and musical longevity, there are sooo many other groups from the golden soul era whose choreography was just as synchronized and enjoyable to watch as their harmonies were to hear. Iâ€™ve compiled a small list of some groups that can easily get overlooked in this discussion. Check out the videos below and rate which group you think has the best choreography!

First up is a group who got their started in my birthplace, Washington, DC. The Unifics may be regarded as a one or two-hit wonder but they made a name for themselves as the ultimate showmen. As a matter of fact, they were considered by some as â€œthe act that no one wanted to follow.â€ One could argue that their routines were over the top, but their stage presence was captivating nonetheless. Watch them work the stage, calling out for justice on their 1968 #1 hit, â€œCourt of Love.â€ (Check out the white gloves too!)

2. Detroit group, The Dramatics (formerly known as The Dynamics), knew how to sing about the ups and downs of love and life in classics like â€œIn the Rainâ€ and â€œWhatcha See is Whatcha Getâ€ (while their frontman was William Howard.) Their down-to-earth harmonies didnâ€™t lose it edge after Howardâ€™s departure. Keeping in line with their previous songsâ€™ themes, the new-look Dramatics also tackled the perils of loneliness in a soulful styling. In â€œMe, Myself and Iâ€, L.J. Reynolds (middle) and Lenny Mayes (far right) alternate on lead vocals, describing the lot of a person who, when alone, â€˜throws away his masqueradeâ€™ and â€˜lets his tears go on parade.â€™ Itâ€™s a sad tale, indeed, but The Dramatics illustrate it in stellar fashion with dynamic footwork. See their performance on â€œSoul Train.â€

3. In 2010, Dr. Gruâ€™s minions got a little bit of â€œBoogie Feverâ€ in the first â€œDespicable Meâ€ movie; that was all possible because The Sylvers brought us that disco hit more than 30 years before in 1976. The Sylvers â€“ like many groups in the 70s â€“ consisted of musically inclined siblings who were ready to take over the world. A pairing with Jackson 5 producer, Freddie Perren, gave them that opportunity, leading to the release of their biggest hits which are synonymous with the â€œbubble-gumâ€ sound. But the family was too talented to be boxed into that style and become â€œunsungâ€; they had not only a great stage presence but also an outstanding songwriter in older brother Leon (who went on to write for The Whispers, Shalamar, etc.) Now, take a look at the group in their prime, getting down with the get down on â€œThe Midnight Special.â€ (In this clip, youâ€™ll see Edmund, James, Ricky, Leon, Pat, Angie, Charmaine and Foster.)

4. After an unsuccessful string of singles, Christopher James/Ollan Bell reformed his group, The Natural Four, in 1972 with three new members. James was looking for a fresh start, and he and his guys got it when they signed with soul man, Curtis Mayfield. Two years later, in 1974, The Natural Four finally hit the charts with â€œCan This Be Realâ€, featuring new member, Delmos, on lead. Unfortunately, the group never had similar success with any follow-up single, which is surprising because they were under Mayfieldâ€™s tutilage, but, you can see the guys groove so smooth to the tune that helped them leave their mark in Soul/R&B history.

5. If someone were to mention â€œsugar pieâ€ and â€œR&B musicâ€ in the same sentence, the first song youâ€™d probably think of is â€œSugar Pie Honey Bunch (I Canâ€™t Help Myselfâ€) by The Four Tops. That would be understandable because that song is the Topsâ€™ signature tune. But, The Joneses, originally from Pittsburgh, PA, hit the charts in 1974 with a sweet song of devotion called â€œSugar Pie Guy.â€ The track is notable for its beginning scatted bass lines, courtesy of lead vocalist, Harold Taylor; but the guys got on the good foot too when they performed their sugary musical treat on â€œSoul Train.â€

I cling to the fact that Iâ€™m an 80â€™s baby, even though I was introduced to the world in the last month of the last year of the decade. So, musically speaking, I was really â€œborn into the 90â€™sâ€ (like R. Kellyâ€™s debut album), and I thus have a special fondness for the R&B of that era.

Aside from the nostalgia factor, the music was actually good and the singers really sang. R&B fans were given timeless music by solo artists like Brian McKnight, Monica, Babyface, and Mary J. Blige, in addition to groups such as Boyz II Men, SWV, Dru Hill and En Vogue. We fell in love with gems created during that time period including Whitney Houstonâ€™s powerful rendition of â€œI Will Always Youâ€ (1992), Montell Jordanâ€™s instant party starter, â€œThis is How We Do Itâ€ (1995), Kenny Lattimoreâ€™s wedding staple, â€œFor Youâ€ (1997), and Deborah Coxâ€™s soul-stirring â€œNobodyâ€™s Supposed to Be Hereâ€ (1998).

Sadly, though, the last decade (the mid 2000â€™s to now in 2014) has hardly produced R&B classics of that magnitude. There have been more than enough catchy radio hits but not enough songs that will stand the test of time. To that end, several artists have weighed in on â€œthe state of R&Bâ€ conversation in recent years, most of whom say thereâ€™s been a tremendous change in the music, namely, digression instead of progression.

For instance, the style has become diluted because nobodyâ€™s really singing from the soul now. Rappers are singing (thanks to auto-tune) and singers are rapping, or at least trying to. Also, artists who had started out strictly urban i.e. Ne-Yo have concentrated their efforts on pleasing the pop crowd and are just now coming back to their R&B fan base. That said, I believe there are many differences in R&B music from the 90â€™s/early 2000â€™s to the latter 2000â€™s to 2014 but Iâ€™ll discuss one â€“ quality of content.

Nowadays, mainstream music thatâ€™s branded as â€œR&Bâ€ is more vulgar and lacks lyrical depth. Speaking of vulgarity, it used to be that only Hip-Hop/Rap albums had the label, â€œParental Advisory: Explicit Contentâ€; but now R&B artists need the same thing because their singles are just as dirty. Yes, R&B will forever be inextricably linked to Hip-Hop/Rap because of how the two genres feed off of each other naturally in music, but thereâ€™s hardly a distinction between the two styles anymore.

Just think about the fixation with the â€˜f-bombâ€™ in todayâ€™s R&B lyrics, i.e., the original/explicit titles of Cee-Loâ€™s â€œForget Youâ€ (2010) and Chris Brown & Nicki Minajâ€™s â€œLove Moreâ€ (2013), as well as the unedited chorus of Miguel and Mariah Careyâ€™s duet, â€œ#Beautifulâ€ (2013). In addition, todayâ€™s â€œR&Bâ€ songs refer to women as â€œhoesâ€ and b*****s, as if theyâ€™re solely objects of menâ€™s sexual gratification. In 90â€™s/early 2000â€™s R&B, though, women were spoken of with more respect.

While the decade obviously had its fair share of raunchy tracks, women were caressed with love and adoration in the average R&B song. In Jodeciâ€™s â€œForever My Ladyâ€ (1991), for example, K-Ci takes the lead in praising the love of his life whoâ€™s also the mother of his newborn child, calling her a â€œladyâ€, not a garden tool or a female dog. That celebratory regard for women is sorely lacking right now, having been largely replaced with a flippant and condescending disregard for them.

Switching gears to lyrical depth, letâ€™s compare two songs based on a womanâ€™s conversation with her boyfriend. In Brandyâ€™s â€œAlmost Doesnâ€™t Countâ€ (1999), she sings, â€œYou canâ€™t get to heaven half off the ground. Everybody knows, almost doesnâ€™t count.â€ Thatâ€™s depth. A life lesson is beautifully woven inside a tale of heartbreak. Though specifically referencing a romantic relationship, anyone can take this advice in life: If you want to achieve your goals, almost doesnâ€™t count; you have to put your all into an endeavor to get what you want out of it.

On the other hand, in Mila Jâ€™s 2014 single, â€œSmoke, Drink or Break-Upâ€, she tells her boyfriend, â€œEither we gonâ€™ smoke, drink or break up â€˜cause the only time we donâ€™t fight is if we drunk or we high (oh my).â€ Oh my, is right! Thereâ€™s absolutely no depth in those lyrics whatsoever, and look at what type of behavior is being promoted to avoid a break-up â€“ smoking and drinking. Moreover, if a relationship is only stable when both parties donâ€™t have full control of their mental faculties, thereâ€™s a serious issue! With content like that making up the R&B of today, thereâ€™s no wonder that Bobby V (an artist who got his start in the 90â€™s group, Mista) said in an interview with rollingout.com, â€œR&B is in a weird place.â€ It definitely is!

Just with that little bit of analysis, itâ€™s obvious that â€œthe soul is goneâ€ in todayâ€™s brand of R&B. Part of the reason is because, as Iâ€™ve heard it said lately, the lines between pop, hip-hop/rap and R&B have become blurred. Furthermore, the usage of foul/derogatory language is indicative of, not only a lack of creativity in writing, but also the respect for what the essence of R&B is. Our beloved genre, which is rooted in storytelling about the struggles and victories in life and love, is in critical danger of losing artists who are willing to put out music that adheres to its true nature. There are some who aim to keep R&B/Soul music alive, including Noel Gourdin, Leela James, Anthony Hamilton and Ledisi, but the majority of popular R&B singers fail in this department today.

This is why modern songs that have classic soul qualities strike a special chord within us â€” tunes like Raphael Saadiqâ€™s â€œLove That Girlâ€ (2008), R. Kellyâ€™s â€œWhen a Woman Lovesâ€ (2010), Beyonceâ€™s â€œLove on Topâ€ (2011), Melanie Fionaâ€™s â€œWrong Side of a Love Songâ€ (2012), Chris Brownâ€™s â€œFine Chinaâ€ (2013), and Tankâ€™s â€œYouâ€™re My Starâ€ (2014). Each composition personifies â€œfeel goodâ€ music because it actually makes you feel good. Rather than brim with vulgarity or mediocrity, the lyrics come from the heart and the melodies breathe soul. Thatâ€™s what R&B is all about, and thatâ€™s what true fans yearn for.

I can say with surety, then, that as sure as my last name is Samuels, the 90â€™s/early 2000â€™s was the last period of time that brought that kind of music on a consistent basis. If I had to sum up my comparison of R&B today and back in the day, what better way to do so than in the words of a song? For that, I quote Atlanta-based singer/songwriter/producer, Jaye Berry, aka â€œJahahâ€, who said in his 2014 single, â€œSoul Musicâ€, â€œWhat happened to the music and the songs that take you higher? Now everything they play just sounds the same (lately) and the artists donâ€™t inspire.â€ I strongly encourage you to listen to â€œSoul Musicâ€ in its entirety (You can watch the video below). If you have become numb to it, youâ€™ll quickly be reminded of just how much heart and soul R&B music has been missing lately!
